Author: Maascamp
Content: My preferred DBMS is Postgres, but I have to use MySQL at work. I can honestly say that moving to MySQL after Postgres is a serious downer. What happens when you want referential integrity alongside fulltext indexes? An ugly database.

Author: floozyspeak
Content: Right now you can't afford to spend money and be wrong.  Yet at the same time you need to make sure that whatever spend goes a long way.  Use your money well, ask clear questions, and get real clear good human actionable toward ROI answers- and then don't stop there.  Take that data, those customers, those people that want X out of your product and use them as part of your marketing and PR materials.  It makes for a good story on the how and why you need to be around.

Author: unalone
Content: Yeah. Although I disagree with the criticism people have given Pressflip. Ted was pretty honest about what he wanted to make: something that did one small thing very well. And, from my testing of it, it does its job very well, and people criticize it for doing one small thing.

Author: KirinDave
Content:
Well they've lost their moral high ground. PressFlip wasn't a particularly great idea, and no one really noticed it.

Who's going to take them seriously when they try and rail on anyone now? Every single comment is going to be, "What ever happened to pressflip? OH YES, I REMEMBER" and then a failmacro image inserted.

I can't see it going well.

Author: mingyeow
Title: How important is user experience when you are still finding your product market fit?
Content:
As a very young startup who is into our third complete revamp of our product, we are constantly facing a question - how much time should we spend on the UI?

The first couple of times we optimized the UI, it was all wasted, as it proved to be the wrong product from a high level point of view. Now on our third iteration, we find ourselves optimizing the UI too, because it is hard to get good feedback with a sucky UI.

Any thoughts?

Author: denglish
Content: It is quite true - both bubbles represented market speculations that outstripped the underlying financial realities. And I believe the reverse can be said that the massive corrections after both bubbles burst are also results of investment confidence dropping below the underlying financial realities. We in the IT sector are very lucky these bubbles didn't align or the bubble bursts may have been much much more severe.
